author: Brendan Wallace

author: Scott Bonjukian
content: Good policy - lidding I-5 is a great way to reconnect our street grid, build more cohesive neighborhoods, and add more open space!

author: Scott Bonjukian

author: Scott Bonjukian
content: This is a great policy - more corner stores should be allowed everywhere! When I lived in Capitol Hill I lived a block away from a coffee shop and mini-market in the middle of a dense multifamily area, and this allowed me great access to daily goods without needing to travel far and it fostered a sense of community as I talked with the regular employees and patrons. This is a traditional form of urban development and should be easy to achieve with no onerous regulations such as parking standards. Indeed, because we are mostly built-out, we need to also add incentives for neighborhood retail such as height/density bonuses and we could even consider subsidies/grants to help the actual businesses startup, especially if run by BIPOC community members.

author: Scott Bonjukian

It is already lined with mid-rise buildings and lots of different types of businesses for the entire length of the peninsula and is served by multiple bus routes. More people should be able to live within walking distance of the California Avenue corridor.

author: Scott Bonjukian
content: The tip of Alki should be designated as higher intensity. It is a fantastic compact neighborhood with a lot of dense multifamily housing, an elementary school, and commercial services, but it still lacks enough density and development sites to attract the biggest thing it needs to be a complete community: a grocery store with pharmacy. More density would also support more frequent transit.

author: Scott Bonjukian
content: The lack of parks and open space in the central/Downtown regional center is very obvious on this map! If we want to direct more housing in these areas and ask people to live very densely, we need to make the regional centers extremely pleasant places to live especially for families with children. That includes adding a large amount park space, but also calming down the arterial streets, more reliable bike and bus networks, building more amenities like grocery stores and elementary schools, and creating more gathering places like community centers and cultural institutions. I know there are some regional centers plans starting up but the Comprehensive Plan is the place to start with establishing a vision for complete urban living.

author: Scott Bonjukian
content: Great policy that reflects the real ongoing work to lid over the Interstate 5 freeway in Downtown and beyond. This policy will help all of the city's departments keep working together with community, state, and federal partners to achieve the vision of a more connected Seattle and creating public space for many of the needed amenities in our densest urban neighborhoods.

author: Scott Bonjukian
content: Great policy that supports a variety of creative options for make better use of our limited urban land and find new open space as we continue to grow. Lidding freeways in particular is an exciting and innovative opportunity since freeways take up so much space in our most dense urban neighborhoods where we are directing population/housing growth, and at the same time lids can reconnect communities with the street grid and new space for recreation and even housing. Excited to see this!

author: Scott Bonjukian

This area is also in easy walking distance to the University of Washington and more dense/affordable housing (e.g. midrise apartments) would provide a lot of opportunities for student housing.

author: Scott Bonjukian

Think big and do park-oriented development (POD)!

content: Many Link stations outside of the downtown core have poor connectivity to the bus network, making them far less useful in the last mile for those who live outside of walking distance or up/downhill.For example, Columbia City Link is served only by Route 50, which has 65 stops and is frequently delayed by traffic, and Route 106, which shares the Link route (and is therefore of limited last-mile value) from Mount Baker to Rainier Beach.Better connections are needed, in particular rapid east-west connections that would provide last-mile access to the Link "spine" for the majority of the city that is outside a realistic walking distance.Implementing these links as BRT would massively increase the utility of Link as a mode of transport, but even more limited improvements like signal timing, express routes, and bus lanes would be a significant improvement.

author: Isaac Gloor
content: Design review needs to be simplified to the point of complete predictability, which is not referenced here. If it exists at all, it should be administrative, not require any public hearings, and should consist only of specific, easily followable rules that can be found directly in the zoning code. Design review processes currently are a major cause of delay in the city, for arguably no benefit. Most of Seattle's most beautiful and iconic buildings were built with no design review process. Many of the buildings that have been built through Seattle's design review process are widely considered to be unnattractive. The aesthetics of a building are prone to the whims of the time and are not relevant to the needs of the city. Please consider eliminating all non-administrative design review, and rolling all design standards into the rest of the development standards.

Parking minimums solely cause harm by adding costs to residential and commercial development. Removing them will not remove parking construction- the market is great at determining how many are needed.

author: Cate Nestor
content: Yes please!I'll start out by saying that I agree with the comments saying that cars need to be a primary focus for reducing noise.That said, generally Seattle's noise ordinances are currently much less strict than they are in other cities such as NYC, and this generally makes mixed use neighborhoods less desirable than they could be (see: recent story about residents near the Ross at 3rd & Pike being disturbed by loud music intended to prevent loitering). Studies have shown that playing loud music leads to higher alcohol consumption, so bar owners have an incentive to crank up the music as much as they're legally allowed to the detriment of the community. We should have laws that allow us to crack down on nuisance businesses who refuse to add soundproofing.

author: Cate Nestor
content: Noise is also one of the top reasons people cite for preferring single-family homes over apartments. Let's ditch the requirements on things like design aesthetics that don't actually impact the quality of life of building residents and instead have stronger requirements on things like sound insulation between units in multi-family and mixed use buildings.

author: Benjamin Keller
content: This fails to acknowledge that Seattle is already operating at a significant housing deficit relative to our position 20 years ago. Maintaining poor performance in housing construction is not going to allow us to become a more vibrant, welcoming, and livable city.

author: Cate Nestor
content: It is important to note that a simultaneously walkable *and* drivable neighborhood is not desirable. I can walk to everything I need in Capitol Hill, but because of heavy traffic, the walk is dangerous and full of noise and air pollution. I'd like to see exploration of "superblocks" similar to those in Barcelona that allow local traffic for residents and deliveries but discourage through traffic. Selfishly, I'd specifically love to see these in the Pike/Pine corridor.

author: Benjamin Keller

author: Melanie
content: Please reconsider the use of parking minimums. By mandating a minimum amount of space dedicated to the storage of personal vehicles at destinations, these places become more unfriendly to navigate for almost every other kind of traveler (pedestrian, cyclist, transit-goer). In other words, these minimums encourage driving instead of reducing it, which will only further increase parking demand in the long run. If the goal is to address parking demand, the solution should be to design cities that decrease reliance on large, space-inefficient personal vehicles that require storage wherever their driver goes.

At minimum, public buildings should meet the CDC guidelines of 5 eACH (effective air changes per hour). Information about ventilation and air quality in public buildings should also be published and easily accessible by the public.

author: Jon Stahl
content: This plan is nowhere near ambitious enough. We need to build lots more housing to catch up with demand, let alone future demand. author: Ian Matic
content: This plan needs to go further. 100k units over 20 years is not enough. Why restrict supply? Let the market determine how many units are needed. Upzone all SFH zoning to at least sixplexes. author: Filip Gouglev

author: Benjamin Keller

author: Reed Butler Hampton
content: This comprehensive plan outlines one of the major issues that has pressed Seattle for the last decade, that our job growth has rapidly outpaced housing growth. This makes no sense and is incredibly dissapointing.

author: Reed Butler Hampton
content: We should both expand our existing urban centers both in land area and in allowable density, but more importantly, we need to make sure that no neighborhood, regardless of wealth, should be exempted from this. Neighborhoods with a history of exclusionary zoning should be the focus of increased density so that density can be more evenly distributed throughout our city. author: Reed Butler Hampton

author: Reed Butler Hampton

Including expanding Urban Centers into historically exclusionary neighborhoods such as Magnolia, Laurelhurst, Wedgewood, and more.

author: Reed Butler Hampton
content: This seems like an incredibly inaccurate statement!! author: Reed Butler Hampton

This plan sets us up for failure.

author: Reed Butler Hampton
content: This is an admirable goal and is required for us to meet our climate goals! I disagree that this plan makes this a realistic goal.

author: Reed Butler Hampton

"neighboring Bellevue anticipates adding 225,000 residents over the same span in its proposed growth strategy." whereas this plan only anticipates adding 200,000 residents to Seattle.If anything this plan results in Seattle taking on a smaller share of the regions population growth thus contributing to exurban sprawl.

author: Reed Butler Hampton
content: I am a big fan of this idea of complete communities! We need to be allowing the kinds of commercial businesses nearby where people live so that the climate-friendly, healthy, safe, and less noisy option is the preferred one!My only concern is that this plan does not allow enough density for these businesses to be successful! They need customers who live near by and we accomplish that by broadly increasing density across the entire city. More than what this plan currently outlines.

author: Reed Butler Hampton
content: We need to BOTH expand Urban Villages AND, more importantly, allow for greater density throughout the entire city. By simply expanding the boundaries of existing Urban Villages (which this plan barely does in the first place) we continue to exempt our wealthiest neighborhoods from change perpetuating the exclusionary zoning policies that have contributed to our homelessness crisis and the inequitable outcomes across our city.

author: Reed Butler Hampton

author: Reed Butler Hampton
content: Goal GS 1.5 seems to not account for the fact that if housing isn't built in Seattle, it will be built in our rural and exurban farmlands and forests. We cannot abdicate our responsibility to the environment. This goal is antithetical to our climate commitments and must be updated or removed.

author: Reed Butler Hampton
content: Goal GS 1.4 seems to continue the legacy of placing the majority of our multi-family housing along loud and dangerous arterials. All people. regardless of wealth, should have the opportunity to live near one of our fantastic parks, regardless of the neighborhood. Looking at the maps in this plan, we fail miserably at this goal by not upzoning near any of our largest, most beloved parks (such as Discovery, Carkeek, or Seward Parks). It seems the hope the OPCD has here is that magically every SFH next to a park will be replaced with a 4-plex which is unrealistic. Please commit to this goal in the stated maps by adding neighborhood centers and urban centers near our parks.

author: Reed Butler Hampton

author: Reed Butler Hampton

author: Reed Butler Hampton

author: Reed Butler Hampton

author: Reed Butler Hampton

author: Reed Butler Hampton
content: The Sunset Hill micro neighborhood is primed for additional development with an established commercial core already. the fact that this neighborhood isn't even getting a neighborhood center goes to show how unambitious this plan is. author: Reed Butler Hampton

author: Reed Butler Hampton
content: Compared to Alternative 5 shown during the drafting process, this draft comp plan adds 7 new neighborhood centers, and REMOVES 21 netting 14 removed Neighborhood Centers. author: Aileen Baker
content: The concept is great, but we've already dropped the ball with execution. Major corridors are not walkable because there's only housing being added--the city needs to require that all multifamily projects have ground-level public businesses/amenities to replace the ones getting torn down.

author: Aileen Baker
content: I think banking on there being that many people who will be sharing space though is disingenuous of this plan. author: Aileen Baker
content: "affordable, efficient, and available, for people of all incomes and backgrounds"This currently feels so profoundly unattainable, and this plan does not seem to indicate how it will actually make our city more affordable, etc. it's so frustrating to read.

author: Aileen Baker
content: THIS.

author: Rehana
content: This is a good goal. Your plan will fail to achieve it.

author: Chris
content: Last comp plan, the city under estimated the projected population growth and the consequences were terrible for housing. Prices skyrocketed across the board. This plan update should learn from that mistake and assume much more population growth than historical plans did. The consequences of having "too much" housing capacity are basically zero. The consequences of not having enough housing capacity are devastating and long-lasting. Do not make the same mistake you made last time.

author: Chris
content: Last plan update the department under estimated the number of new residents and the consequences were devastating for housing price of both for-sale and rental properties. Do not make the same mistake again! There are almost no consequences to "over planning" for housing growth--the worst case outcome is the market does not build as much housing as the city has zoning capacity to absorb, and supply keeps up with demand. If you under-plan for housing, the consequences are runaway costs and thousands of middle and lower-income people in the city suffer. Please plan for more housing production.

author: Chris
content: The city has displacement risk maps. New capacity for housing should be targeted in the areas where displacement risk is lowest. That means more housing in the richest, whitest neighborhoods. Equity means everyone participates in the solution. Do no continue to let the richest, whitest neighborhoods exempt themselves from being part of the solution. I want to see big changes in places like Queen Anne, Madison Park, Magnolia, Wedgewood, Laurelhurst, Madrona.

content: It's fascinating that by the city's own admission, housing production over the last decade didn't keep up with demand, and then continues to double down on the existing bad policies that got us into this position. Who's running this ship? We need a new captain.

author: Andy Randles
content: This is counter to any vision of environmental friendliness. Offices should be built throughout the city. Allow people to live close to their offices, reducing vehicle miles travelled.

author: Donnie  Munson
content: To expand non car transportation we need to focus new housing developments along new transit infrastructure, around this infrastructure we should remove single family home zoning and subsidize building affordable multi family housing in these areas to meet housing demand.

author: Samuel Patera
content: This plan does not represent the interests of the city or its residents. It ignores the growing population and the need for more housing and especially affordable housing that is grossly underrepresented. It should eliminate single family zoning, and provide for more dense zoning around anywhere served by transit, not just along busy, dangerous, unhealthy arterials. This plan falls short of state objectives, and even the objectives of neighboring cities like Bellevue. It is a violation of the minimum recommendations and what was voted on in good faith by voters, and would damage and cripple our economy, environment, and neighbors. Please put forth the more bold changes the voters want and need, and help Seattle not fall behind other big American cities that are taking the proper initiatives.

author: Ian Lee
content: The growth target for housing should be higher if that many new jobs are anticipated.

author: Isaac Gloor
content: We should be focused on expanding housing in any form- including towers and large apartment buildings along with middle housing- even if it comes at the expense of some arbitrarily defined view. Most view points in the city are only accessible to the ultra wealthy.

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: This is unsubstantiated, uncreative, and wildly misleading. If we were willing to narrow roads on city-owned right-of-way and replace some city-owned parking facilities (including within parks) with green space or other amenities, we could expand open space without acquiring new land. What does it mean that "Seattle is largely built out"? Is a single family home with a large lawn part of built-out Seattle? If so, does "built out" actually just mean privately owned? It irks me that the plan would include this statement as though it has a clear meaning and is demonstrably true.

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Putting most of our new housing along arterials on which we've repeatedly demonstrated we're unwilling to slow cars down and from which we've been unwilling to limit the space allocated to private motor vehicles is not a strategy likely to meaningfully reduce automobile dependence

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: We're not even maximizing the housing that can be built around upcoming light rail stations. This isn't serious.

author: Isaac Gloor
content: What impact? High-density housing provides something incredibly important: housing! This framing makes it seem as if we only allow high-density housing begrudgingly, when the overwhelming response from the public when asked about this plan was that we wanted dense housing everywhere. High-density housing doesn't need to justify its existence. Low density housing, however, should have to, when it is the most expensive, exclusive, and inefficient use of land in Seattle.

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: As another commenter suggested, "share" means "proportion". This plan actually sets us up to account for a smaller percentage of upcoming housing growth compared to other cities, certainly relative to our size. In the case of Bellevue, we'll even contribute a smaller share in absolute terms.

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: This framework doesn't mention clear and quantifiable goals. It just says we should measure data and analyze the data. We can't have accountability without goals/commitments

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Planning for Increased Homelessness would be more accurate. The plan laid out here essentially guarantees that our homelessness crisis will become worse

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Here's a nice big elephant in the room. We can't talk about equity and righting historical wrongs and keep Laurelhurst zones the way it is.

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: A lot of density missing from this frequent transit route

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: No upzoning whatsoever along this frequent transit route and the lowest-density designation on its entire east flank and the near part of its west flank. This is unserious.

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Look at this beautiful frequent transit route alongside an amazing park. We need to upzone here!

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Why is the east side of this frequent transit route exempt from upzoning?

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Frequent transit, minimal density. Not good enough.

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: We need density near this park. Parks shouldn't be reserved for the wealthy

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Lovely park with frequent transit access. We should allow more people to live next to it!

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: This is incredible. Look at this stretch from 65th all the way up to 125th with frequent transit yet the lowest possible density. People deserve to live in NE Seattle!

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: If they're this important, how are we not expanding them more?

author: Ryan Kaufman
content: This number is far to low to accommodate the population growth projections, and the yearly growth # here (4.5K) is lower than recent building numbers. In general it seems like this draft plan falls frustratingly short on the most important thing here, housing supply (which will benefit residents at all income levels). The city needs to be more ambitious in growing the supply of housing.

author: Joseph Kraemer
content: Perhaps we should also consider "redesigning" neighborhoods that are already overtaken by traffic and storage of private vehicles. We can't just look at new neighborhoods, but also consider already established ones.

author: Joseph Kraemer
content: Love this, I hope we can reclaim public lands like Lake Washington Blvd so that people can enjoy this space without being in constant fear of hit by a car. These cars ruin the natural environment and scenic appeal of these places. Similar to Centennial park. We should really give beautiful scenic spaces like this to pedestrians and cyclists who can enjoy it.

author: Joseph Kraemer
content: Don't allow the NIMBY's to weaponize historical value of SFH zoning areas. We need to allow this city to increase in density to allow for population growth

author: Joseph Kraemer
content: I get that it should be somewhat gradual but please allow for flexibility for density increases. If there is demand for tall buildings, that means that the city needs the density and preventing will only hurt residents and increase cost of living.

author: Joseph Kraemer
content: LU 4.7 has no business being here. Setbacks aren't relevant to urban design. So many cities in the world don't have minimum setbacks. Let property owners decide how they want to use their land.

author: Joseph Kraemer
content: I can already identify the major noise generator. Its cars. So yes, lets regulate them. Make pedestrian only streets, remove lanes to reduce the number of vehicles on the road, add speed bumps and reduce speeds on roads. Add bike lanes and bus lanes to encourage alternative modes of transportation.

author: Joseph Kraemer
content: get rid of this. Let people build what they want. Let people be creative and have interesting visual designs.

author: Joseph Kraemer
content: No. Remove parking minimums. Allow private businesses to decide how much of their space they want to dedicate to the storage of massive private vehicles. Let the free market decide the appropriate amount of parking spaces.

author: Joseph Kraemer
content: Yes. Absolutely remove parking minimums for buildings that are close to transit stops.

author: Joseph Kraemer
content: Yes, we don't need to require it (just like we shouldn't REQUIRE PARKING) but we could offer incentives for businesses to install safe and secure bicycle and scooter parking.

author: Joseph Kraemer
content: Perhaps we shouldn't have a gas stations at the intersection of one of the most pedestrian friendly intersections of Cap Hill....

author: Joseph Kraemer
content: Please, please allow this. Everyone wants neighborhood cafes. I want to be able to walk coffee shops, restaurants, bars and stores. Please allow for more flexible land use. I don't want to have to drive everywhere.

author: Joseph Kraemer
content: Please consider increased density. We need larger FAR values to accommodate for expected growth.

author: Joseph Kraemer
content: Yea, we should really discourage underused parking. This land space could be better used. Perhaps replacing underused parking with mini parks or bicycle parking.

author: Joseph Kraemer
content: Make sure we don't allow NIMBY's to weaponize historical districts.

author: Joseph Kraemer
content: I hope that one day the spaces will be so safe that I feel comfortable having kids around. There are just too many cars in "pedestrian" spaces.

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Penciling in Magnolia for you

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: There are so many large stretches along frequent transit corridors that are not represented by dots on this map

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Nothing around Discovery Park?!? The comp plan says we want to encourage density around parks

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Park deserving of density

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: There should be more density on this side of Jefferson Park

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: "Urban Neighborhoods will contribute to making Seattle a more affordable and racially inclusive city"This isn't true. This is wishful thinking. Given the projected job growth, limiting upzoning in these vast swathes of the city to just these low-density housing types will mean that Seattle becomes less affordable faster. You don't have math or projections that will support this assertion. At best, adding these housing types because state law insists on it will make Seattle the tiniest bit more affordable than a future where you don't allow these modest upzones. It won't make Seattle more affordable than it is today.

author: Joe Kraemer
content: How about no parking?

author: Joe Kraemer
content: If we are expecting this much growth, shouldn’t we also be allowing for housing density increases?

author: Joe Kraemer
content: Yes please. Increasing the pedestrian and cycling access to transit hubs will allow many more people to use them. Then this will decrease cars and traffic congestion.

author: Joe Kraemer
content: Walking and cycling is the greenest transportation!

author: Joe Kraemer
content: Private vehicles are a terrible thing about American cities, Single occupancy vehicles are the worst

author: Joe Kraemer
content: We need protected space for cyclists on more roads. It’s incredibly dangerous without them. This will also encourage more people to get out of their cars and thus reduce traffic

author: Joe Kraemer
content: We need to also make it safe for people to cross streets. We need to implement traffic calming measures to slow speeds and protect pedestrians. Take a look at some of the Dutch methods such as street narrowing, leaving cobblestone, and making elevated pedestrian crossings

author: Joe Kraemer
content: Excellent. We should be prioritizing these styles of transportation.

author: Joe Kraemer
content: Maybe we should totally remove conflicts by creating pedestrian only streets in locations of incredibly dense commercial spaces like pike place and broadway in cap hill.

author: Joe Kraemer
content: Anything but vehicular storage please.

author: Joe Kraemer
content: We really need more routes under 10min. Consistent, frequent, dependable transit is what will get people out of cars. We dont want to worry about when a bus will come

author: Joe Kraemer
content: I hope these are all protected lanes. Adding some paint to a street doesn’t make it a bike corridor.

author: Ryan Wilson
content: Seems like an important metric would be % of the population that is within a 5-10 min walk of a neighborhood center (or urban center). I really appreciate the neighborhood center concept and am looking forward to more of a 15-minute city; but there are significant "gaps" in the map in which some areas of the city don't have a nearby neighborhood center and thus still will not have access to the amenities these neighborhood centers provide.

author: Allen
content: Add language to support highway removals, which the current administration is funding elsewhere in the country, not just lids.

author: Allen
content: Single-family homes are not subject to design review, so neither should apartments. End design review and stop delaying housing the city desperately needs.

author: Allen
content: North Greenwood should be an urban center given its access to transit.

author: Ryan Wilson
content: I think this is actually a good goal as long as it does not substantially hinder more housing where it makes sense. Agree with a previous comment that this is something of a secondary goal.

author: E.J. Foust
content: 800 ft. is ridiculous and worthless. I would advocate for at least a 1/2 mile.

author: Jason
content: Connectivity to transit alone is not enough. More emphasis needs to be placed on treating bike, bus, and light rail infrastructure as one cohesive system. That means adding more bike parking at stations and ideally implementing a city-wide bike share program to help solve the last-mile problem.

author: Allen
content: Concentrating density along arterials isn't equity.

author: Joseph Kraemer
content: It would be really great if we could create dedicated streets for cyclists. Bike highways!

author: Michael
content: Capitol Hill is an extremely transit dense and walkable neighborhood. I think the regional center here should be expanded east to 23rd to allow more growth in this area. Additionally, I think that the building height and density limits should be relaxed especially on the west slope of the hill to allow for taller and denser developments. Many of these taller denser buildings already exist in the neighborhood, more should be allowed to be built

author: Michael
content: I think the city should be bold and upgrade Fremont and Wallingford to regional centers as well. Given the neighborhoods' proximity to transit, job centers, and amenities, greater density would enable more people to live closer to where they work, run errands, and play. Rather than creating islands of urban density in a sea of single family homes, I believe the city should allow the already dense neighborhoods north of Lake Union to grow into a continuous urban environment

author: Michael
content: Why are vast swaths of low density zoning still allowed this close in to the city? This plan needs to be way more ambitious to address the city's growing housing needs

author: ron hornung
content: This is the worst feedback page ever make by the city, to let two or three people post hundreds of the same messages is just wrong.

author: Michael
content: This is an insane amount of low density zoning for one of the fastest growing cities in the country. This map clearly demonstrates the lack of vision and ambition by the current conservative city council. Seattle has the potential to become an elite global city, yet our city's leadership clings to their delusion that we will forever remain a provincial backwater

author: Michael
content: Why not incorporate this entire area into the downtown/first hill/capitol hill regional center? The distinctions are subtle enough that they will make little difference in practice

author: Michael
content: The lack of ambition and vision presented in this plan is astounding.

author: Amelia Bryant
content: Parking minimums are an outdated concept and always lead to promoting car usership over other means of transport. At the very least, just remove parking minimums altogether and let developers/business owners decide how much parking they think they need.

author: Amelia Bryant
content: Housing abundance is a great goal and one everyone in Seattle would agree with. But, it seems as though this plan will not allow the City of Seattle to even come close to housing abundance.

author: Jeremy Drouillard
content: I am all in favor of this goal, but I don't think the current iteration of this plan accomplishes it. The minimal up-zoning in non-urban centers creates neighborhoods where a walk or bike for an everyday trip like a grocery store is too far or dangerous. The residents of these low-density neighborhoods end up driving to the dense urban centers for these everyday trips. Who can blame them? Unfortunately, this means the urban villages bear the brunt of this car dependency, by needing wider, faster roads and an abundance of parking.

author: Ryan Wilson
content: Please make sure that when the rubber hits the road that these options (particularly sixplexs) are actually buildable. I know this has to do with setbacks and floor area ratio. More sixplexes and 2-3 bedroom apartments are what this city sorely needs, not necessarily more townhouse clusters.

author: Ryan Wilson
content: And most of these multifamily buildings are very small apartments. We need to figure out how to increase production of 2-3 bedroom apartment buildings.

author: David
content: There are many ways to design intersections that increase visibility for pedestrians and motorists while slowing traffic speed at very low cost.

author: David
content: Pedestrianize busy areas like Pike Place.Add automatic bollards to restrict access for farmers markets and events.

author: David
content: To reduce traffic on Admiral and California, there is a need for a frequent (every 5-10 min max)  shuttle service - maybe a smaller bus - that links Alki, Admiral Junction, Alaska Junction and Morgan Junction.

author: Reed Hampton
content: The fact that Magnolia, historically one of Seattles wealthiest and most exclusionary neighborhoods is at most getting a single neighborhood center with a radius of only 800 ft flys in the face of this supposedly "OneSeattle plan". Magnolia, like all of our other neighborhoods should be expected to contribute to the vitality and economic development of our city and not remain an exclusive enclave for the wealthy. There should at minimum be additional neighborhood centers in this peninsula, ideally an Urban Center in downtown Magnolia would go a long way to righting historical wrongs (and in helping justify the cost of replacing the Magnolia Bridge)

author: Jim Dunbar
content: This draft is woefully inadequate and needs drastic changes to make any sort of a dent on our housing affordability crisis. It is of the utmost importance that you rezone or otherwise allow more apartments in more places. The most logical and the one that would yield the most bang for the buck are parcels on the arterial routes you noted in your draft. With the existing transit service those are not single family areas despite the zoning and represent a great opportunity to build a lot of units without significant backlash. If a bus rolls by your home every 10 minutes you are not living in a single family area. Just make this zoning correction to reflect the facts on the ground.

author: Reed Hampton
content: I feel like the lack of a Regional Center in West Seattle is a glaring omission. This is a neighborhood that is receiving not just a Light Rail station, but a dedicated line to and from it. This extremely rapid transit comes at a great cost and it makes sense to upzone these neighborhoods so that we as a city can fully benefit from this investment.I feel this is emblematic of the lack of vision in this draft plan. We need to be bold, and we won't solve any of our problems by nibbling around the edges of solutions.

author: David
content: Need to provide bigger apartments for families. None of the new apartment buildings have more than 2 bedrooms.Also build condos, instead of townhouses. If you are a young parent, you don't want to climb several flights of stairs to get to the bedrooms+ so much space lost in stairs.

author: Reed Hampton
content: The lack of expansion of these urban areas is a serious concern, Why should Regional Centers contain most of Seattle's office development? This seems to run counter to the stated goals of making Seattle a 15-minute city in which all residents are close to places of work. If we require everyone to commute to the same place at the same time, why are we surprised VMTs aren't going down and congestion is bad?

author: David
content: Homeownership opportunities are inexistant due to the lack of affordable condos. Why not build 1,2 bedroom condo buildings that will enable young couples to move out of apartments and start building generational wealth.

author: Reed Hampton
content: 2,000 units of housing in Northgate over 20 years?? That is one large apartment building every 3 years (my apartment has 317 units). How can this draft plan be taken seriously when the city is planning away the benefits of our multi-decade investment in transportation infrastructure? The area around all major light rail stations should be receiving the highest density of zoning, expanded urban boundaries, and more homes.Simply put, this does not cut it.

author: Bob
content: A comment on the demographic questions-- cis and trans men are men, cis and trans women are women, nonbinary people are nonbinary, and transgender is NOT a gender. If you want to know how many trans people are in your audience, include a separate question for trans status (i.e. Do you identify as transgender?)

author: Reed Hampton
content: It's clear that what the Mayors Office and the OPCD want here is emphatically not OneSeattle but two. One Seattle which is able to afford to live in our city, and another that is priced out and is forced to endure long, carbon intensive commutes, in and out of our city every day. This is abundantly clear when this "OneSeattle" plan plans for over 50,000 people to work but not live in our city.

author: Reed Hampton
content: Magnolia, one of Seattles most exclusionary neighborhoods, should be getting an Urban Center. For all of this plans talk in the introduction about righting historical wrongs, it continues to perpetuate the exclusionary nature of our city by protecting already wealthy neighborhoods from change.

author: Reed Hampton
content: Phinney Ridge should absolutely be an Urban Center. This is already a semi-dense neighborhood with access to frequent transit (King County Metro 5), public amenities (Zoo and Woodland Park), biking infrastructure, and many walkable shops and destinations.If the city hopes to meet any of its stated goals, we cannot be ignoring the potential of these neighborhoods!

author: Franklin Lewis
content: Almost a full year delay for this garbage. The bozos who planned us into this mess are still screwing up. Rezone the transit routes to allow max height apartments on that street. Then 4 floor apartment buildings within a block or two. Then 4 story apartment buildings on every corner lot throughout the City. Think big and do something! This plan is beyond weak and must be strengthened.

author: Reed Hampton
content: The Delridge neighborhood is receiving massive investment in the form of a new Light Rail Station and yet remains underzoned for this investment in this comprehensive plan. This plan should be visionary and plan for housing abundance for our neighbors, particularly in neighborhoods receiving such large transportation investments.

author: Reed Hampton
content: I agree with the other commenters that Urban Centers near Light Rail stations should be allowed considerably higher height limits. I'd also point out that many of the new Light Rail stations being built don't even have an associated urban center! It is ridiculous that every Light Rail Station is not zoned to at minimum an Urban Center!

author: Reed Hampton
content: You're missing Magnolia in here. It's long past time to correct the wrongs of our historically exclusionary zoning policy.

author: Reed Hampton
content: Adding in Delridge here for you as well as this is another neighborhood receiving major investment in new high capacity, sustainable Transportation infrastructure.

author: Reed Hampton
content: There are so many "local commercial cores" which are not included as neighborhood centers on this map it is incredibly disheartening. The OPCD should view these as the uncut jewels of our city, opportunities for growth and increased housing affordability encouraging sustainable living choices. But the exclusion of neighborhood centers like Sunset Hill, Carkeek Park, West Woodland, Upper Magnolia, and so many more shows how little vision this document has.

author: Reed Hampton
content: Upper Magnolia should have an additional neighborhood center (as originally planned), it provides access to Discovery park, great bike infrastructure, and there are already small shops near by. This classification meets so many of the criteria defined elsewhere in this document but is just not represented in your maps!

author: Reed Hampton
content: The majority of land area in our city should not be zoned for this low density of housing. This comprehensive plan will struggle to maintain housing costs at their current levels and doesn't even attempt to dig us out of the hole we have already dug ourselves in to.

author: Reed Hampton
content: I am wholly supportive of 2-6 plexes across our city (as is required by state law). But the devil is in the details. Floor Area Ratios need to be high enough for construction to make economic sense, set backs need to be reduced to allow for sidewalk style commercial developments, design standards need to be relaxed to reduce development costs.

author: Reed Hampton
content: Corner stores are amazing! A great way to support small businesses, create a sustainable city, and encourage shopping local! Just make sure to remove setbacks allowing these businesses to be sidewalk adjacent, increase FARs to allow for home/business hybrids, and most importantly, remove parking minimums! The goal of allowing these small businesses should be to encourage walkable neighborhoods, and parking minimums will just make our neighborhoods parking lot craters!

author: Reed Hampton
content: I am all for job creation and think it is important to maintain our strong industrial base, but we need to provide housing for these people IN our city! We cannot expect them to endure long commutes to work here, they deserve the right to live near their worksites.

author: Reed Hampton
content: It is a shame we don't allow more small scale commercial activities in our parks. Being able to grab a coffee in Carkeek, a bagel in Discovery Park after a run, or enjoy a glass of wine at Golden Gardens would be an immense improvement to our shared park space and would be a major draw to get more people to use them!We should NOT be limiting this usage to existing buildings but should be exploring how do we enhance our existing park assets to make them more attractive to Seattleites. Could we add an ice cream parlor to Lake Union Park in the Summer, there's plenty of open space for it!

author: Mieszko
content: The West Seattle junction(s), Alaska and Admiral, warrant being combined into a full regional center, with more dense infill allowed in between and around them. These two areas are already the hottest and most expensive areas in West Seattle, and and this plan seems to barely increase the allowable development here. Currently the area turns into full suburbia as soon as you go more than two blocks away from California Ave, especially if you go west. These areas are so close to all sorts of amenities (and soon light rail) and are just begging to be up-zoned. All of the values expressed in this plan are great, and I fully support them, but the execution and policies need to be an order of magnitude more ambitious to reach the stated goals.

author: John  Doherty
content: Policy LU 2.20 is in direct contradiction with Seattle's stated goal of increasing the amount of housing for all and increasing density. This policy would only restrict density unnecessarily. Please remove this policy from the plan.

author: John  Doherty
content: If Seattle is serious about confronting the housing crisis and reducing homelessness, the city must drop policies LU 4.4 and LU 4.5. Restrictions on building height artificially reduce the supply of housing and increase prices for all. The city would alleviate many of its problems by simply saying yes to skyscrapers and taller buildings throughout the city.

author: John  Doherty
content: I agree with the other commenters. LU4.18 must be dropped as a policy. Seattle should seek to streamline reviews, not "seek excellence". This policy only serves to restrict our housing stock further and add multiple roadblocks to the process where there does not need to be any.

author: John  Doherty
content: The city should dream bigger. When creating new light rail stations, if the stations are above ground then upzoned, tall, dense housing should be present at the site.

author: John  Doherty
content: Ensuring that buses arrive on time should be included as a goal. It doesn't matter if a route is labelled as "10 minutes" if the buses are consistently delayed and the arrival times are unreliable.

author: John  Doherty
content: Policies H2.1 and H2.3 are two of the most important policies mentioned in this  document. They should be the heart of it. However, much of the document is completely opposed to these policies. Mainly the goal of only building 80,000 more housing units, which does not even reach the minimum mandated by the state which is even mentioned in this document!Expanding our housing supply and creating housing abundance would require setting ambitious goals like a million new units over the course of the next 20 years. It would also include more detailed call outs for how the land use code, design reviews, and permitting process can all be stripped down and simplified. Also, one of the easiest ways to increase supply further would be to stop restricting building height and volume (FAR and similar ratios), especially in densely zoned areas.These considerations should be heart of this document and in it's current form these parts seem little more than empty gestures.

author: John Quinn
content: One of my favorite things about Chicago’s neighborhoods is the seemingly random shops dotted throughout the streets. Since everything was walkable, I’d walk to the neighborhood grocery store. I’d walk to the neighborhood gym. I’d walk for every thing I needed. They weren’t all in some center — they were seemingly placed in some random spot in the neighborhood. I do wish that we would adopt a similar policy. Let small businesses serve the neighborhood where they think is best, and open up residential development across the entire neighborhood. It has worked in Chicago’s Lincoln Park neighborhood, and I’d like to see the same approach here.

author: David B.
content: Yes! Even before the pandemic, Downtown has always been  a ghost town after 6 or 7 pm, the result of planning that catered exclusively to 9-5 office workers and the occasional convention.

author: Lisa
content: Downtown has FAR too many land use zones. Let people build what they want. Remove LU8.2 entirely, and remove the complex web of differing land use zones downtown.

author: David B.
content: Under the wildly unambitious growth strategy outlined earlier in this draft, how is this true for _every_ area? What is, say, Magnolia's role?

author: Lisa
content: The goal should be reducing the number of people to rely on personal vehicles as their best or only option.

author: Lisa
content: These are great goals but Seattle has had similar goals for years, and we have seen very, very limited progress, or even regression, from them.

author: Lisa
content: Enforcement of these policies has to be a policy explicitly called out. Single-occupancy cars have experienced priority for a century, and therefor feel extremely privileged. They will feel a "loss" of their rights when these policies are implemented, and will have the incentive to not follow them (speed, destroy infrastructure, park where they want, drive on sidewalks and bike lanes, etc). This will contribute to safety problems. Strict enforcement of the space for more vulnerable users, ie, those outside of two-ton metal boxes, but be prioritized.

author: Lisa
content: The Madison Rapid Ride doesn't run all the way to Madison Park because rich mansion-owners were allowed to prevent it. The rapid ride should be extended to give people access to the lake and increase density in Madison Park. It is designated as an "urban center".

author: Lisa
content: Need Bike+Arterial infrastructure in this area, on 23rd/24th Ave specifically. Everywhere else involves extreme hill climbs and significant added distance.

author: Andy Randles
content: The past city council said loud and proud they don't actually care about this when they voted down a zoning change for a few parcels in SoDo to allow for a new housing development. Put your money where your mouth is and vote to allow for more housing options close to jobs.

author: Lisa
content: The bus-to-light-rail connections are currently very poor. For example, why do you have to cross the bus station and a very busy wide road to get from where you get off the bus to the LR station at Mt. Baker? There aren't even signs that indicate the way. Why can't the bus just use the drop off area at the Mt Baker station? There are similar examples all over the city. What should be a 1-min connection ends up being a 10-minute connection, making the entire system unusable.

author: David B.
content: Why should the burden of being educated on and following the rules be shared equally by "all users of the street", when it's a single type of user – car drivers – who cause all of the serious injury and death on those streets? Any dollar spent on campaigns to scold pedestrians for wearing headphones is a dollar that could've been spent on better pedestrian infrastructure.

author: Lisa
content: Designating streets as "freight class" makes them impossible to make safe for pedestrians, bikes, and other users in the current environments. Freight should not be prioritized over other users, on ANY street. Freight interests fight safety investments, speed limit decreases, infrastructure like bike lanes and raised crosswalks, road diets and lane narrowing. Thus far they have been successful in cancelling these type of investments. If we are going to achieve the great goals listed above in the transportation section, the freight network needs to be seriously reevaluated and reduced.

author: Lisa
content: Remove the word "efficient". Things need to move from one place to another, but they do not need to be moved efficiently. They need to be moved slowly, carefully, and with respect for other uses.

author: Lisa
content: Recommend rewording this goal to "Reduce speed limits to enhance safety". Reducing speed limits everywhere is necessary to enhancing safety, not only "where necessary". It is worded in a way where interests (ahem, freight, and cars who are just passing through) will argue that it is not necessary.

author: Lisa
content: This is a waste of money and effort. Enforcement is needed to protect all users from car drivers.

author: Lisa
content: Trucks and freight interests routinely fight against and gut any proposed safety improvements.

author: Lisa
content: The "Urban Villages" concept is a continuation of the legacy of racial exclusion and inequity, yet this plan calls it a "success" and builds upon it.

author: David B.
content: Every unit of new housing built within the city represents a huge long-term savings on VMT by housing someone who might otherwise have been forced to commute into the city. Transportation impact fees disincentivize new construction and are counterproductive to the city's stated goals.

author: David B.
content: This policy is in direct conflict with the existence of a design review board and process as outlined in LU 4.18.

author: Ryan W
content: 35th Ave NE has been previously identified by the city as well-positioned for higher densities. This is one of the least dense areas of Seattle, why not allow for more neighborhood centers in this area?

author: Stephen Siciliano
content: Why is there no Neighborhood Center for Alki?

author: Ryan W
content: Sand Point Way is one of the largest transit corridors in NE Seattle. With very low displacement risk, this whole corridor should be higher density

author: Ryan W
content: Having an urban center in Lake City is great, but far more of this corridor deserves to be higher density

author: Ryan W
content: Interbay and North Queen Anne are a massive area with frequent transit and future light rail service. A single neighborhood center here seems very inadequate

author: Ryan W
content: Roosevelt Way and 45th St could provide huge connectivity between Wallingford and Roosevelt respectively but seem very underutilized right now

author: Stephen Siciliano
content: There should be a rule of thumb that no housing in Seattle is > 15 minute walk from the core of a Neighborhood Center (or more intense usage). That's the only way to actually meet climate goals -- making local access without a car needed fast and easy. The frequent transit network is good but we shouldn't expect everyone to get on a bus for 30 minutes to go get groceries.

author: Ryan W
content: Will Beacon Hill not receive any neighborhood center? This feels like abandonment of a strong neighborhood

author: Ryan W
content: Georgetown is a significant region of Seattle, and a neighborhood center designation feels somewhat inadequate for the area

author: Stephen Siciliano
content: The 50 in Seward Park was at one time a frequent bus (I think it was downgraded in the pandemic), so it should be on the future frequent corridors even if at the moment it's not running frequently.

author: Stephen Siciliano
content: Corridors that are planned by Metro in their Long Range plan (such as 28th in Magnolia and 32nd in Sunset Hill) should likewise show up here as future frequent corridors.

author: Ryan W
content: This is planning to not even meet the minimum level of housing that Seattle needs. If Bellevue is adding more housing than Seattle, this plan has serious problems.

author: Jack E
content: Homeownership only builds wealth if home prices continue to rise, which is the opposite of what the city should want.

author: Jack E
content: This completely invalidates everything that came before. Lofty goals are stated, but the actual plan is to do the opposite. If this is what you want for Seattle, you want Seattle to become more unaffordable and more unequal.

author: Jack E
content: But the planned new housing is not enough for the new population? What is the point of this plan at all?

author: Andy Randles
content: Why would we ever encourage height limits in a downtown core? This is a city, not a suburb.

author: Andy Randles
content: What does this even mean? Cut the red tape and let downtown develop organically. You're strangling the very thing you claim to love.

author: Andy Randles
content: This tries to dictate human behavior, and if planners have proven anything, it's that they do a very poor job of understanding human desires. The best city infrastructure and places that people might refer to as "charming" (i.e. Pioneer Square, Historic Ballard, etc.) aren't even allowed in most modern zoning codes. You've proven time and time again that you get this wrong. Remove the barriers and the market decide what should or shouldn't get built.

author: Andy Randles
content: What's with the fixation on heigh limits?

author: Andy Randles
content: Desirable to whom? Let the market decide what's desirable.

author: Andy Randles
content: Yes, more of this please!

author: Andy Randles
content: Love this idea! We don't need anymore land use that encourages driving.

author: Andy Randles
content: Yes! More corner stores!

author: Andy Randles
content: Yes, please!! PS streets are so dangerous for peds on gamedays. Cars zip and zoom around, without regard for people on foot. I'm so happy to see this is being notated and I'm looking forward to SDOT addressing this.

author: Andy Randles
content: The Walgreens at Denny and 7th is not a site of "exceptional significance" despite what the Landmarks board and CC argued. It's so hard to take documents like this seriously when these are the types of buildings that are described as carrying "exceptional significance".

author: Andy Randles
content: What's so incredibly frustrating to read is that city is absolutely obsessed with preserving these neighborhoods because of their charm, but will absolutely not permit these same types of neighborhoods to be copied throughout the rest of the city. Why? What possible reason could the planning department fabricate for this?

author: Andy Randles
content: If you could somehow get rid of the surface parking lots and few abandoned buildings in Pioneer Square, that would be an actual Christmas Miracle.

author: Andy Randles
content: There's nothing smart about parking infrastructure. Just support transit and dense housing options and we can get rid of any investments in "smart parking".

author: Andy Randles
content: Hell yes!! I'm excited to see some specifics on this, and glad that the topic of fewer cars on the road and more pedestrian/bike friendly alternatives is taking center stage.

author: Andy Randles
content: How about 2 million? Let's talk some real numbers here and grow like we deserve to.

author: Andy Randles
content: "automobile" and "accommodating growth" do not go together. We know the automobile does not scale.

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: This will get easier and easier if this plan goes forward, as fewer people from these groups will able to afford living in Seattle. The first step in redressing equity harms would be to allow more density in predominantly white, predominantly wealthy, predominantly SFH-zoned neighborhoods. Permitting the minimum upzoning required by state law will not cut it

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: How will you zone these areas if they are annexed?

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: We should look to DECREASE the rewards that accrue to people based on their having acquired property. With or without private property ownership, our city is a shared space. Our air is shared, our water is shared, and to some extent we share an economy. That we have dual classes of citizens based on property ownership (which often means inherited wealth) is a bad thing, not a good one

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: What does this mean? Would it be terrible if some lesser-used streets or blocks became park space? Housing? Pedestrian-only paths?

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: "enhance overall topography" is not a meaningful concept. What could it possibly mean to "enhance" topography? What topographies are better? Our comprehensive plan shouldn't speak like there's a clear shared value at play here

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Wait, so the logic is that if we have lower heights by the lake, we're allowing people in towers further from the lake to still have views? This feels like a pretty sneaky way of making sure the people who already own SFHs near water don't have any neighbors they don't want. It seems fine to step up heights, but you could do that just as easily by starting with 10 stories by the lake and increasing by one or two stories every block

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Consider that Manhattan has tall buildings and it's great

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: What does it mean to consider the nearby physical context? It could mean anything. We could value a range of heights and aesthetics in the name of variety just as easily as the implied preference of valuing homogeneity. There's a lot of phrases like this in the plan with no clear meaning. Ok, I've considered the nearby physical context. Now what?

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: What impacts are to be encouraged? What impacts are to be discouraged? Is the suffering of our unhoused neighbors an impact we wish to consider?

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Yes, this would be marvelous. I'm glad we're proposing to allow more corner stores, but there's otherwise not a ton in this plan to further this policy goal

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Right, can we say exactly why it is that gradual transitions are to be preferred? This is another example of stating a policy without stating what value it's meant to serve

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: We can measure a lot of these things, but not the visual qualities and the aesthetic values. Improving drainage and floor resilience as well as reducing air pollution and heat island effects are really worthwhile. But codifying vague aesthetic preferences into city policy is much less worthwhile. What's more, if we want more trees, we ought to be willing to give up some parking and somehow tree preservationism hasn't prevented vast racial and economic disparities in tree canopy coverage. It has mostly been a tool for wealthy families to prevent housing near their single-family homes

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Do you have standards for adequate light and air? Keeping these things vague is a way to let vibes substitute for explicit policy goals, which usually results in preventing more housing from being built

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Let's call this what it is: allowing a small group of city planners to define and impose aesthetic values upon an entire city. This is a bad goal.

author: Matthew Wiecek
content: There are few urban centers that extend to the waterfront. Alki is already well developed with some apartments, consider creating an urban center along the water near Alki Beach. This would be consistent with the stated goal of putting density near parks and would finally give people of more modest means a chance to live by the water.

author: Matthew Wiecek
content: A different comment proposed narrowing the urban center here. As a resident of Queen Anne, I strongly disagree. The urban shops and apartments lining Queen Anne Avenue are what make it so pleasant. We should be expanding it to allow for the amenities to extend farther instead of being confined only the one street. Plus, apartments here mean that people of more modest means would get to live on the hill and have easy access to a school for their children instead of being an enclave for the wealthy as it is now.

author: Matthew Wiecek
content: There seem to be an awful lot of frequent transit lines in the north of Seattle, and yet these remain zoned for low density. Either we should be more aggressive about creating urban centers here or we should cut transit service and shift those resources to the urban centers.It doesn't make sense to provide high-levels of expensive urban service to low density sub-urban areas.

author: Matthew Wiecek
content: LU 8.1, 8.2, and 8.3 should be removed entirely. There should be no restrictions on height, design, or residential vs commercial use in downtown. This is a city and downtown serves a functional purpose, putting restrictions on it hampers not just the city, but the entire State of Washington.

author: Matthew Wiecek
content: We should have explicit goals and policies around removing lanes for cars as well as on-street parking over time as they do in Paris. If we are serious about our climate change goals, we need to remove space from cars are reallocate it towards busses, trams, bicycle infrastructure, and sidewalks.

author: Matthew Wiecek
content: I'm noticing that this area of North Seattle has a lot of Premium and High Priority transit corridors. However, we can see from Figure 2 that these are all planned to be low density areas.If we choose not to upzone this area, we should remove frequent transit from this area and reallocate it to urban areas. Precious transit resources should be deployed in dense urban areas, not wasted on low-density sub-urban areas where they will be underutilized.

author: Matthew Wiecek
content: Discovery Park is the crown jewel of our park system. Yet it looks like we don't intend to connect it to frequent transit. Given that it's located in Magnolia, which is planned to remain low-density in this plan, it looks like we intend Discovery Park to remain an enclave for wealthy, car driving individuals.This is a shame and a missed opportunity to expand access to Discovery Park.

author: Matthew Wiecek
content: The 8 is one of the highest ridership bus lines in the entire State of Washington. However, it does not appear to be listed as a potential future RapidRide corridor. The Uptown (Lower Queen Anne) to Capitol Hill segment should be put up for consideration.

author: Matthew Wiecek
content: Recommend adding a policy to prioritize automated enforcement of traffic safety laws (like speed limits with speed cameras) and automated enforcement of bus lanes throughout the city.

author: Matthew Wiecek
content: Please remove T 9.10. Density justifies transit investment in the first place. Impact fees disincentivize density and are counterproductive. If impact fees must be levied, they should be levied on low density forms of development that are car dependent and therefore costliest to support.

author: Matthew Wiecek
content: None

author: Matthew Wiecek
content: Your own plan acknowledges that increasing supply lowers housing costs and displacement risks. By definition, any new development that increases density lowers city-wide cost and displacement pressure on lower-income individuals.H 3.15 should be removed entirely.

author: Matthew Wiecek
content: Denser housing is more affordable housing. H 3.3 requires allowing higher density in all neighborhoods. I will note however, that apartments will remain banned across the majority of the residentially zoned land under this plan.

author: Matthew Wiecek
content: H 3.12 should be removed. Inclusionary zoning is a regressive tax on renters. inclusionary zoning because it's really just a tax on renters. The affordable housing units have to be paid for somehow and it's going to be paid by passing on the cost to the other renters in the building. The ones paying market rate.The problem, of course, is that renters tend to be younger and lower income than homeowners. Any which exempts wealthier homeowners from contributing while sticking renters with the bill is regressive. If we really want to subsidize housing, we should raise property taxes to pay for it. Yes, some of that will get passed on to renters via higher rent as well, but at least homeowners will contribute too.

author: Matthew Wiecek
content: This just looks like a restatement of H 3.12 where we're going to impose inclusionary zoning requirements. I already placed a comment there, but we should remove H 3.20. Inclusionary zoning is a regressive tax on renters that exempts wealthier homeowners from contributing to affordable housing. It is inequitable.

author: Matthew Wiecek
content: High density development has lower per-capita costs to utilities. Recommend adding U 1.4 - charging lower rates to those in higher-density housing to acknowledge the fact that their per-capita costs are lower.In addition, since people who live in apartments are younger, more diverse, and lower income than single family homeowners, density discounts are equitable and help counteract the regressive nature of our tax system. If we charge single family homeowners and apartment renters the same rates, then apartment dwellers are subsidizing wealthier homeowners, which is regressive.

author: Whitney Rogers
content: So many of our current neighborhood parks are designed around recreation for children and organized sports. I would live to see parks with exercise equipment for adults.

author: Whitney Rogers
content: I notice this section says nothing about dog parks. Given that dog parks are utilized extensively, especially considering year-round use versus other kinds of parks, and that Seattle has a comparatively high number of dogs, it seems like dog parks deserve to be a growth goal. Many studies have found health benefits to pet ownership, and dogs are the most popular form of pet ownership - young girls with dogs get an extra hour of exercise PER DAY when their family has a dog; for adults living alone, pet ownership correlates with slower cognitive decline; just petting a dog or cat has been shown to lower blood pressure.  Yet without dog parks, the benefits of dog ownership are disproportionately enjoyed by those with the wealth to purchase a home with a large yard - an increasingly rare luxury. Dogs are also the most common kind of service animal, and dog parks give people with disabilities more ways to take care of their service animals. This means dog parks are an equity issue, too.

author: Whitney Rogers
content: We have ample evidence that when Seattle-based employers with work-from-home (WFH) capabilities allow their employees to work from home, we greatly reduce the number of vehicle trips. We should be offering incentives for employers to encourage their staff to WFH 3+ days per week, if we actually care about reducing carbon emissions.Downtown will be better revitalized by increasing housing, retail, and arts residencies. Yest, it will take time and investment. However, commuters who resent the city for telling companies to put butts in downtown chairs are not looking to spend money or time downtown anymore. Those who had the opportunity to WFH during the pandemic had a shift in priorities, so there is no "going back" to how things were. Instead, we need to adapt, which will ultimately create a better downtown, and happier residents and workers.

author: Heidi C Madden
content: Re: LU 2.7: The wording "Encourage the preservation and expansion of the tree canopy" is far too weak and vulnerable to inevitable exploitation by developers.  Please change to "Require the preservation and expansion of the tree canopy." Our trees are vital to the protection of all the people in Seattle. The one truly inclusive thing we can do right now which will benefit us for years to come is to protect and expand our tree canopy.

author: Heidi C Madden
content: Re LU 2.9 Please study the negative impact that ugly architecture has on human health. The international movement called "Architectural Uprising" has shared multiple studies and research indicating that beauty in architectural design is directly linked to improved human health. (architecturaluprising.com) Hence, the wording in this paragraph, "Encourage the preservation of characteristics and features that contribute to communities' multiple identities . . . " is far too weak and vulnerable to exploitation. Developers should be required to follow stringent aesthetic guidelines if we are not to have the entire city covered in more of the sad, ugly, and unhealthy boxes that we are currently seeing.

author: Heidi C Madden
content: This concept is idealistic, but it fails to mention how we are going to get the parked cars off the streets.  People will still HAVE cars because, realistically, not everyone can ride public transportation to every function they attend.  Electric car use is growing exponentially and should be encouraged. The only logical answer is to REQUIRE new construction to include an adequate amount of off-street parking. I know this goes against the city's long-held tradition of letting developers get away with little or no parking requirements, but now that we are steering the ship in a better direction, something needs to be said about where the cars will be parked, because they are not going to magically vanish.

author: Heidi C Madden
content: None of this mentions using what we already have. Downtown is recovering slowly, but it is still a shell of its former self. Converting more half-vacant office buildings to housing may be a simple way to revitalize downtown and make it an attractive place for people new to the city to live, especially if they are also going to be working downtown. Add more practical conveniences, such as grocery stores and tiny dog parks, and make downtown vital and attractive again without having to break ground on new buildings. Converting existing buildings may be more cost-effective, and those savings can be passed on to the new residents.

author: Sam Jaeger
content: Any higher density upzone will result in a net-decrease in fossil fuel consumption and carbon emissions as a result of a higher walk score. While the impact of the increase in utility usage is something to make note of, cities around the world have been growing for millennia and most are not environmental disasters. An environmental review of said upzone feels like a red herring in effort to over-complicate the upzone.

author: Dan Hernbrott
content: It feels like this map describes Seattle as it currently is, and not as we'd like to see it grow in the next twenty years, especially given the projected population increase. If we do not increase density within the city, it will only lead to sprawl, increasing our car dependency and decreasing quality of life.At the very least, we should see much more density around our parks and transit corridors.

author: Leonardo
content: Transit oriented development is just induced demand. It solves nothing. People far from the stations will just drive. If you want to increase supply, regulate short term rentals, tax investor owned homes to make them a bad investment and give tax breaks to owner occupied homes. That will keep whatever supply you buld from being gobbled up by cash buyers in bidding wars.

author: Flora Tempel
content: Please continue to call this area North Rainier/Mt. Baker - unless you want to try to rename the Link Light Rail Station. It creates confusion among community who has had to adapt to their neighborhood name changing.

author: Flora Tempel
content: As a CBO in SE Seattle, it is unacceptable that our relatively small area, about 1/6th the total land of Seattle, has such a high proportion of Urban Centers. Although I understand that there is some sort of logic happening here (it seems like a political logic to me), there should be some sort of analytic metric used as well. I recommend a minimum % of area to be designated Urban Centers. Upgrade some of the Urban Neighborhoods, particularly in North Seattle, as many are suggesting here.

author: Elizabeth Day
content: The regulations in this plan limits what can actually be built, and favors the development of smaller homes that wouldn't adequately house a family of four. I live in a 1200 sq ft house with my family of four (because I can't afford to move someplace bigger in Seattle) and it's tight, and many of the units likely built from this plan would be smaller than that.

author: Elizabeth Day
content: This plan does zero things to encourage development near schools and increase enrollment. Neighborhoods near elementary schools are generally excluded in this plan from dense housing.

author: Flora Tempel
content: From my previous comment, I meant upgrade some of these Neighborhood Centers - these seem to be reflecting simply current development rather than being aspirational, as a 20 year plan should be. Some Urban Centers should be designated as such because they make sense to encourage growth in. 35th is a good example of an area that is already naturally growing, but needs some incentive to get there. I know it won't be politically popular, but that doesn't mean it doesn't make sense.

author: Elizabeth Day
content: It appears almost all neighborhoods near elementary schools receive only the most basic generalized zoning changes, which do little to increase density and school enrollment.

author: Flora Tempel
content: This seems like only 2 areas. Where is the map of the 3rd area?

author: Elizabeth Day
content: "Policy decisions", such as the Urban Village growth strategy, which was considered racist under the City's own evaluation using the Racial Equity Toolkit, which this plan doubles down on.

author: Jenna Chavez
content: I think it's ironic that we are acknowledging as a city that we need more housing but the plan doesn't even come close to the amount that we need, and doesn't even allow for as much as the STATE is requiring. Those rules are usually made by the state to prevent small cities and towns from trying to not allow increased density.  It's pathetic that we are the largest city in the state and don't want to even abide to those rules. Sounds like a NIMBY came up with this plan.

author: Jenna Chavez
content: Hopefully our mayor realizes how he will ruin our transit for years to come if he continues to push for these ridiculous alternatives instead of having a station at chinatown. People are going to have to deal with construction regardless of where the station is, at least don't screw the people of chinatown by forcing them to walk far to access transit, as well as the rest of the city by not having a central hub where our transit riders can transfer. If this happens, it will be a regret of the city for the next hundred years and they will remember which administration caused this disaster.

author: Jenna Chavez
content: How are we aiming to create more of these walkable neighborhoods when the increased density is still limited to the same areas (ie: Ballard, U-District, etc)? Without the dense housing, it will only be walkable to the few blocks of single family housing that lives near the Main Street, and if you don't have enough density, you cannot support enough businesses to stay afloat to allow it to be a walkable neighborhood. You are setting the neighborhood up for failure.

author: Jenna Chavez
content: I feel like you are confusing Seattle with Manhattan. There is so much more density we could have if this plan was really aimed at allowing increased density and more housing. Instead, it's allowing NIMBYs to stay NIMBYs in their single family houses, and more people to be pushed out of Seattle because there isn't enough housing causing the housing places that are available to increase their costs of homes or rents. We are not even close to being built out. That's just a ridiculous statement.

author: Jenna Chavez
content: This is what should be our goal, not what will happen with this current plan.

author: Jenna Chavez
content: It's embarrassing that Bellevue plans on building more housing than the city of Seattle. How is that sustainable when it leads to more people living in Bellevue and driving into Seattle?

author: Jenna Chavez
content: Yet we are doing minimal to tackle housing? We know we are expecting this amount of growth, yet are creating policies that limit our density to urban centers/villages to help accommodate the growth. Why are we planning for failure? It boggles my mind.

author: Jenna Chavez
content: Again, we should be focusing on that but this plan doesn't even come close to this. It's so strange to me because the plan is telling me we have the huge problem that needs to be fixed but then says we should put a band-aid on a gaping wound. Does that sound like an effective tool?

author: Jenna Chavez
content: But you're not even trying to increase the supply with this new plan. It's only 20,000 different from the previous plan, which this plan admits wasn't enough.

author: Patrick Aupperle
content: Our primary high-capacity transit system is a single tram line and some busses. The city should really be looking into significantly increasing capacity and frequency here. The tram is already very crowded and is not set up to support future growth.
