author: Heidi C Madden
content: What will be required of developers as far as providing off-street parking for all these new units? I know idealistically cars are not encouraged in favor of mass transit, but in reality it will take a while for transit to catch up with the new growth. Also, many people who commute to work on transit still own cars for other purposes. Instead of the unrealistic approach of expecting folks from all walks of life not to own cars, electric cars should be encouraged. Require developers to including parking as part of any housing plan, with extra bonus points for also providing e-car and e-bike charging stations.

author: Heidi C Madden
content: No housing in parks please.  We have the rest of the city to use for housing. Parks need to be left for the entire city population to enjoy. It's s slippery slope when we start allowing housing in parks.

author: Andy Randles
content: More loading zones would make a lot of sense in places like Broadway on Capitol Hill and other areas with high pickup/delivery. Right now it's so chaotic around these spots for peds/bikes/cars/transit because of all the food delivery services misusing the ROW.

author: Elizabeth Day
content: While I agree with other commenters about how Seattle is hardly "built out," what about activation of public golf courses for use by other forms of recreation?

author: Ankur Dhoot
content: Seattle is not largely built out - large swaths of land are still dedicated to parking lots or free curb parking. There is ample space to build more housing.

author: Ankur Dhoot
content: The existing strategy concentrates growth on dangerous, loud, and polluted arterials like Aurora. This is not an equitable growth strategy. We should be allowing more growth than just triplexes and fourplexes in "nice, residential" (a.k.a previously single family zoned) areas as well.

author: Ankur Dhoot
content: Great! Walking, biking, or transit should be the primary modes of transportation.

author: Ankur Dhoot
content: I wouldn't consider the majority of urban villages as "walkable" today. Most still have quasi highways running through them (e.g 15th Ave NW in Ballard).

author: Charlotte Fallarme
content: Be sure to consider the negative impacts of not permitting tall buildings soon enough. This mistake was made in the U district where, during a building boom in the 90s and early 2000s, oppressive height restrictions resulted in the construction of wide squat buildings (around 5 stories) on just about every lot that was suitable for redevelopment. Now that 20 story buildings are allowed, there are way fewer places to put them without tearing down relatively new and very expensive wide squat buildings.

author: Charlotte Fallarme
content: A particular amount of pedestrian traffic should not be a prerequisite for permitting a store on a given corner, since the introduction of the store would likely increase the pedestrian volume.

author: Charlotte Fallarme
content: A corner store should be allowed to co-exist with housing on the same lot if the lot is large enough for them. A residence above the store might be common (provided the store is large enough), but it should not preclude additional residences behind the store, both attached and detached.

author: Charlotte Fallarme
content: We should not go backwards by reducing below today's levels the total square footage of housing that can be built on a given lot. Whereas ADUs, each having their own floor area limit of 1,000 square feet, are currently exempt from the FAR (Floor Area to lot size Ratio) limit, it appears that under the new proposal all homes will be included in the FAR limit. It looks like this has the potential to reduce the total square footage of housing that could be built on smaller lots, particularly those under 5,000 square feet. There are many such lots in close-in neighborhoods that have the most amenities and where the need for high density is greatest.

author: Ankur Dhoot
content: "Impacts of a use on other properties..." is giving adjacent property owners leverage to continue to block development. This should not be a policy if we want to build more housing.

author: Ankur Dhoot
content: Does this mean we now have a policy for getting rid of highways and arterials in Seattle?

author: Andy Randles
content: Love seeing this language! Bring back COVID-era outside dining!

author: Eric
content: Why not up zone areas where future light rail will be? Like the West Seattle to Ballard line.

author: Chris Cook
content: This doesn't appear to be a vision of housing abundance at all, but rather the bare minimum required by state laws. "Space Needle thinking" would be a plan that prepares for 500,000 new units or another BIG goal.

author: Chris Cook
content: I am rather confused at how preventing marginalized areas from adding new housing will be beneficial to preventing displacement - it will either drive the price of these areas up even more through lack of new supply (increasing displacement) or potentially dissuade new public or private investment in the areas, keeping them from material gains. What is the purpose of this?

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: We shouldn't codify things we can't define. Design review board elections don't have nearly the participation they would need to be considered remotely democratic, nor are the processes for defining "design quality" very democratic.

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: In what way should it respond to the neighborhood context? Should it look to mirror it? Contrast with it? Neighborhood contexts HAVE never been frozen in time, nor should they be. If a proposal goes into design review and someone objects that the project "doesn't respond to neighborhood context?", what would that mean and how should it be dealt with? How would any applicant or review board member prove or disprove assertions about responding to neighborhood context? This will just be used as an ill-defined invitation to forestall development.

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: The factors discussed above are impacts of the EXISTENCE of off-street parking, not impacts of the REQUIREMENT for off-street parking. If demand for off-street parking in private developments is high, developers will be incentivized to build it, whether or not it is required. The requirement tips the scales irreversibly and makes it harder for developers to respond to actual demand in an area

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: If demand is high for parking, why would we need requirements to ensure the demand is met?

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Can we require housing where demand for housing is high?

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Why is competition for on-street parking bad? Why does it need to be reduced? If this is your reasoning, you should explain it

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Why does requiring alley access to off-street parking limit impacts on pedestrians? Cars emerging from alleys without looking carefully post major danger to pedestrians and it's generally harder for pedestrians to see these cars coming than cars traveling on regular streets.

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Why is it that this plan considers it necessary sometimes to require automobile parking but never considers it necessary to require bicycle parking? This is a glaring inconsistency.- Does bicycle parking facilitate accessibility?- Does it reduce competition for on-street car parking? What about for on-street bike parking? - Does bicycle parking encourage use of transit, walking, and biking?I'm not advocating that we require bicycle parking, but I am saying that the stated rationale for requiring car parking ought to apply just as well to bicycle parking and the fact that we require on and not the other shows something blinkered in the approach and the rationale for it.

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: What would compatibility mean? Define your terms!

author: Eric Mullen
content: While I'm sure that a golf course that's light rail accessible is nice, what would really be great would be dense housing accessible via light rail. We should take a hard look at why we are using this land for something people want (golf) rather than something people need (housing), and consider rezoning the land to accommodate dense housing, especially near the future light rail stations.

author: Eric Mullen
content: Montlake, especially north of 520, needs to be upzoned. This area never gets touched by any upzoning, and leaves extremely expensive single family homes untouched, within short walks of the light rail station. This has to change: upzone Montlake!

author: Eric Mullen
content: There are so many great neighborhoods and destinations on every shore of lake union, yet it takes 3 different bus lines to effectively circumnavigate lake union. There should be a ring bus line (#33?) that goes around the lake (or rather one in each direction).

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: What does this mean? Safe how? How will large volumes of pedestrians agree on attractiveness?

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Are there really major institutions that have insufficient parking at this juncture? I would think it's more likely that universities, hospitals, and other institutions have an oversupply of parking and an under-reliance on other modes of transit

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: Excellent. Downward, I hope.

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: This is good. This plan does not evince enough consideration of people with disabilities.

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: We should tie it to specific things to turn to, like removing lanes of vehicular traffic.

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: This should include adding vehicular barriers between the roadway and the sidewalk on arterials that lack a protected bike lane between motor vehicles and pedestrian walkways

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: This means protecting these individuals from the INEVITABILITY that cars will leave roadways where fast speeds are possible/common

author: Kyle Jacobson
content: I think one-way streets are an underutilized tool here, as reducing traffic from two-way to one-way often makes it possible to reclaim a lot of street space for non-automotive uses

author: Jacob McCracken
content: I am confused as to why the the City isn't leveraging the Social Housing Developer more in this plan? Especially given the mandate from the voters and the expanded tools provided by the State of Washington. The current and future housing needs of Seattle aren't going to be met with bare minimum solutions - it's time to throw everything and the kitchen sink at this crisis. That means leveraging the Social Housing Developer to the fullest and creating permanently affordable and equitable housing in concert with the tools provided by the state.

author: Matthew Crane
content: Single-family zoning should no longer be the minimum residential zoning anywhere in the City of Seattle. The minimum should be quadplex city-wide, with density bonuses for affordable housing developments.

author: Matthew Crane
content: There should be more of these areas along key corridors like Aurora, 15th Ave NW, etc. where there is already existing frequent transit service.

author: Matthew Crane
content: Please add Skyway to this plan.

author: Matthew Crane
content: This means de-prioritizing the automobile and I think that change should be more-explicitly stated here. The status quo is not sustainable or in alignment with our city's goals.

author: Matthew Crane
content: Corridors and centers.

author: Kelabe T.
content: With the limited land to expand our city's open spaces we must provide access to our current open spaces by increasing density near the open spaces we already have.

author: Kelabe T.
content: This worked well on Lake Washington Blvd. and should be expanded to many more streets near the water or greenbelts throughout the year.

author: Kelabe T.
content: This should include adding and maintaining free public restrooms throughout the city so people can better enjoy public spaces.

author: Kelabe T.
content: Absolutely need to have more indigenous land stewardship going forward.

author: Kelabe T.
content: Would love to see some investment in making some of our other business districts more accessible by transit and bike routes as well.

author: Kelabe T.
content: Especially in neighborhoods that have a high risk of displacement or have historically faced displacement (i.e. Chinatown/ International District and the Central District)

author: Andrew
content: It would be great if this would go further and include a policy to consider converting streets to be fully pedestrianized, i.e. car-free.

author: Kelabe T.
content: Please strengthen this language. Convenient could mean many things. I would love to see people have close and easy access to food in all neighborhoods.

author: Andy Randles
content: The city better plan to build a lot more housing and commercial activity in those neighborhoods if it's serious about reducing VMT. That means grocery and corner stores where now we have grocery deserts, and dense housing near those new stores to support them.

author: Andy Randles
content: Posted limits are irrelevant without good street design.

author: Andy Randles
content: We all know that this is just a tax on renters. Any new fee to build new housing becomes a tax on those who will be living there. There's nothing equitable about impact fees.

author: Andy Randles
content: There's no abundance anywhere in this plan.

author: Andy Randles
content: We need a plan that allows and encourages a whole lot more homes to be built before our market rate housing is affordable. We know that greater supply will naturally lower market prices for a given good, but for whatever reason this plan encourages only very limited growth and housing supply. Our fixation with remaining a city with suburban-style living throughout much of our land will only leave property prices high and unobtainable for much of the population.

author: Andy Randles
content: The city dictates this process. Only you can fix it.

author: Andrew Tait
content: Why is the Urban Center on 130th Light Rail not connected to the north/south bus route?  Please work with KC Metro to assess east/west bus routes through this new Urban Center.

author: Andy F
content: This new urban center is very important to making the new 130th street light rail station anything more than a nuisance for riders. The area between Northgate & 145th, from Aurora to 15th Ave NE is nearly devoid of any restaurants, coffee shops, retail, or other services that would make this stop useful for anyone but the local residents. The Haller Lake neighborhood is currently one of the least walkable areas in the city. Local residents must travel more than a mile for basic necessities, and must walk either on streets with no sidewalks, or along very busy streets with narrow, poorly maintained sidewalks.This new urban center in this location would be a huge benefit to both neighborhood residents and regional residents looking for services with easy access from transit hubs.Please keep this in the final plan.

author: Riley Avron
content: We're in a housing crisis and this is a city-owned *golf course* directly adjacent to an urban center at which a multi-billion dollar Link extension will arrive in 2032. At a minimum, make this a lovely public park. Just take down the fences. Ideally, allow development of some of the land for car-free dense housing. The region has changed dramatically since the golf course was opened in 1940, and it's time for this golf course to change with it.

author: Deborah Rose
content: I am most concerned that this discussion of housing does not include the density impacts on canopy cover and stormwater runoff that are clearly indicated in the EIS (specifically for the Light Rail Development areas). The vision needs to include protections for environmental values that are key to liveable neighborhoods.

author: Mark DeLoura
content: As a member of Uptown the changes here over the past five years have been a little whiplash-inducing. Understanding the impact of the last round of upzoning prior to making even more changes would seem wise.

author: Galen Ward
content: I semi agree with the comment on trees. Trees are important and we need to do more to keep Seattle green. They are however not more important than people and sacrificing development in Seattle just so we end up cutting down more trees outside the city.Seattle can have more trees and middle class housing if we eliminate setbacks, allow 4-plexes everywhere, allow taller buildings so developers can avoid trees, and incentivize street trees.

author: Spencer Garrett
content: The Downtown regional expansion into Uptown & Queen Anne would work better if it ran straight Northward between Queen Anne Avenue and Taylor Avenue North until Prospect Street or Highland Drive. The westside of Queen Anne already has very large apartment buildings so expanding there really doesn't accomplish much added housing. Plus the Eastside of Queen Anne has more transit routes, is closer to job centers, has more developable parcels and much fewer apartments. Hope you take this into account.

author: Jim Dunbar
content: This draft is woefully inadequate and needs drastic changes to make any sort of  progress on our housing affordability crisis. I have a few ideas that think would help a lot. To start with and most importantly you have to rezone or otherwise allow more apartments in more places. The most logical and the one that would yield the most bang for the buck are parcels on the arterial routes you noted in your draft. With the existing transit service those are not single family areas despite the zoning and represent a great opportunity to build a lot of units without significant backlash. If a bus rolls by your home every 10 or 15 minutes you are not living in a single family area. Just make the zoning correction to reflect the facts on the ground.

author: Franklin Lewis
content: Planning is really missing the mark with this draft. You need to max out the height for apartments on frequent transit routes. These are the only hope for anything near affordable. You know full well that the expanded urban centers such as in Madison Park, Magnolia or Queen Anne will be anything but affordable. Quit fooling yourself and giving false hope to others. Use the frequent routes to the maximum, four/six units just does not cut it and is a massively wasted opportunity if done.  Hope it's not by design but just more of the foolishness that got us into this mess in the first place.

author: Jennifer Tillman
content: Please make it possible to have more large apartment buildings in the City core. Living without a car with shops, parks, services, etc is only possible in the core. Good bus service is also really important for getting to work. In the plan it seems you are only looking out for the rich tech type that can buy the townhomes. There are a lot more of us who need a place to live that allows us to enjoy the city. Please help!

author: Taryn Greenwood
content: There is huge demand for more neighborhood cafes- the neighborhood coffee shop nearest to me in Cap Hill always has a line out the door because it's one of the few coffee shops with ideal placement- among the apartment buildings people live in!- as opposed to on a main commercial/mixed zone like Broadway or Pike/Pine. The corner stores and cafe near me were a huge draw when choosing an apartment- the desire is absolutely there!

author: Nerbles
content: Is this misspelled? Polices or Policies?

author: Nerbles
content: This plan was crafted by but does not cover police engagement. If they're going to drive all over us, shouldn't there be some type of engagement to help them realize we're people and they can't just get Mike Solan to pay a fine for killing us?

author: Stephen Siciliano
content: Today if you want to walk / bike along the coastline there are numerous gaps in all-ages safe pathways. I'm not just talking about pedestrianizing Lk Wa Blvd, but actual missing connections -- e.g. you can't get from Madison Park to Foster Island, from Smith Cove Park to 32nd Ave in Magnolia, etc... We should prioritize continuous access alongside the sound and Lake Washington.

author: Stephen Siciliano
content: This should be true but is not today. Downtown needs vastly more housing to be a true core of our city.

author: Wilson Bailey
content: The only height limits we should have are FAA ones. If we want an affordable and livable Seattle, we need as much housing as possible within city limits. If that means 30+ story apartments, that's fine. If NIMBYs complain about apartments "ruining the character of the neighborhood", just look at some of the big apartments in the U District. They don't ruin character. Seattle is a rapidly growing city. Our cityscape should reflect that.Likely won't happen for the foreseeable future, but we should rezone all residential zones to mid to high density multi-use. That is how we can become a 15-minute city.

author: Wilson Bailey
content: We should have overnight Link service to and from downtown, as well as better off peak headways. It can be like the Night Owl bus service, maybe 20-30 minute headways single tracking between stations. That would promote more trips to and from downtown

author: Wilson Bailey
content: We should replace this with parking maximums. It would incentivize biking, walking and better transit

author: Wilson Bailey
content: Seattle is a growing city. Its "character" is that of more and more apartments popping up everywhere. NIMBYs can complain all they want, but apartments are the character of the city, NOT gentrified single family housing that prevents racial mixing and further pushes minorities out of our city.

author: Wilson Bailey
content: So... mixed apartments, right?Oh, never mind. The council is too NIMBY for that. Legalize apartments everywhere. That is how we house everyone equitably

author: Wilson Bailey
content: We should do what Chicago is doing and put a tax on high value property transfers and use that money to build more public housing for low income people and the homeless. That is how we can make Seattle great and overcome our homelessness problems.

author: Wilson Bailey
content: To prevent gentrification and displacement, you need more housing. Its simply supply-demand economics.Legalize apartments everywhere. Upzone the entire city. Upzoning prevents gentrification instead of causing it. Its simply the truth.

author: Wilson Bailey
content: Sixplexes must be the bare minimum. If we are to get out of our affordability crisis, we need to remove red tape and allow developers to build up.Upzone the city to mixed use and high density residential and incentivize high density apartments. That is how we get out of the crisis, not by legalizing two and fourplexes.For all NIMBYs out there, the character of Seattle is changing. We are a growing city, and a rapidly growing one at that. The character of Seattle is high density apartments, mixed use development, and much more transit, bike and walking accessibility.

author: Wilson Bailey
content: We should also improve transit access to these areas. Accelerate Ballard Link and get the proposed Georgetown Link line built.

author: Wilson Bailey
content: I've said this many times throughout this document:Legalize high density apartments everywhere.But especially around Link stations. If we want to justify our rapid expansions, rapid densification around stations must also happen.

author: Ryan Wilson
content: Upzoning this area above Golden Gardens seems like a slam dunk for a Neighborhood center - aligns with the goals of providing more people access to parks and it's already a neighborhood with frequent transit.

author: Wilson Bailey
content: We should have all day Sounder service on the N and S line. I know ST is thinking about all day and weekend service on the S line, but having all day Sounder service on the current network would be amazing. It would boost ridership tremendously, especially since post-covid commutes are much more often during the day instead of rush hour.Also, it would incentivize more expansions, perhaps some branch lines in the South Sound area and to places like Stanwood (Paccar would like that)I know BNSF (and UP) own the track, so it would be tricky to get this done. But we have to. Link isn't a silver bullet - taking Sounder from Seattle to Tacoma is much faster than what it will be on Link. Same between Seattle and Everett. If we are to have equitable transportation access to communities outside Seattle, we need expanded Sounder service, and frequent (1hr-30min) service.My personal wish: Electrified (overhead) Sounder mainline. BNSF may complain, but India manages double stacks. We can too.

author: Ryan Wilson
content: Why not just extend the urban center to incorporate all of North Delridge? This area will be super well-served by light rail very soon with two adjacent stations. It should definitely be upzoned.

author: Tyler
content: 2,000 units for Northgate incredibly low. The area largely is a giant pit of nothing or the empty parking lots of a dead mall, essentially a blank slate. If there was ever low hanging fruit in this city for an upzone, this is it. Please look at what Vancouver BC is doing around their SkyTrain stations for inspiration.

author: Tyler
content: Please increase FAR as number of units increases! The FAR needs to be large enough so that LIVABLE dwellings that are actually desired by people are built. From what I have read of the plan, it currently does not do this and makes anything that is 4 units or larger unbuildable or incredibly cramped.

author: Connor Stein
content: The development patterns encouraged in the updated neighborhood residential concepts are actually the complete opposite of climate resilient and sustainable. Replacing one single family house with 4 detached units that are almost touching will leave essentially no space for trees and ensure that new developments will be dominated by paved surfaces and hot, dark roofs. More importantly, this plan will do NOTHING to address Seattle's housing affordability crisis. More and more people will be pushed out of the city while making super-commutes to work. Truly shameful work coming from the city on this one.

author: Brian Flynn
content: What a laughable and pathetic draft. Renaming Villages to Neighborhood Center but doing the exact same policies fools no one. You want to keep people out and maintain your suburbia in the city. No apartments just more of the same failed policies of the last 30 years. Rip this garbage up and start over, it stinks.

author: Connor Stein
content: Very common L by the city on this one. They're doubling down on the same planning strategy that directly led to the disparity between communities (the urban village strategy)!! The city has produced so many resources mapping areas with "high access to opportunity." These are neighborhoods with low risk of displacement which historically have been shielded from development by the urban village strategy. If the city is serious about equitable growth and access to opportunity, then they should read their very own Planning Commissions report, "Seattle 2035: Growth and Equity: Analyzing Impacts on Displacement and Opportunity Related to Seattle’s Growth Strategy." Why bother even having these commissions if you just ignore all of the work they do?

author: Connor Stein
content: It doesn't seem very equitable for most new housing to be built next to busy, loud, and polluted arterials while all those who "got theirs" enjoy quiet, tree-lined streets.

author: Connor Stein
content: If the goal is to produce a diversity of housing types to meet the needs of all Seattle-ites, then you need to allow more types of housing everywhere. As it stands now, this plan will mostly encourage 3- and 4-pack townhouses with poor access to daylight and ventilation and a proliferation of stairs. Rowhomes and townhomes should rightfully be part of any growth strategy, but they shouldn't be the ONLY option. We need cottage courts, stacked flats, small apartments, mid-rise apartments, etc, etc, etc.

author: Connor Stein
content: A home shouldn't be a financial instrument. Simply put, if people weren't so extremely rent-burdened or house-poor then they would have more disposable income to save or invest.

author: Connor Stein
content: "Largely built out" is a laughable description of Seattle.

author: Connor Stein
content: I agree, which is why all of the city should be more aggressively upzoned. At a bare minimum, every residential lot in the city should be zoned for 6 units.

author: Connor Stein
content: I wonder who lives in these areas close to frequent transit and amenities like our wonderful city parks?

author: Connor Stein
content: Intersecting frequent transit lines and access to parks and amenities - where is the density?

author: Connor Stein
content: This ridiculous bottleneck of housing density along 45th is a symptom of this city's obnoxious pandering to single-family homeowner NIMBYs.

author: Phillip Wiggins
content: What an epic fail by the city. After thousands of comments and an insane year long delay this hogwash is the big reveal? Village strategy just renamed. Areas near transit squandered by not allowing apartments. Face it, they want to just collect the in lieu of fees from these expensive projects and build holding pens way north or south so they never have to see working folks outside of driving, delivering or serving them. How dare the peasants want to live just a little closer to their jobs. What a letdown. Thanks Planning, you house boys for the rich

author: Connor Stein
content: Why does this area of the city, much of which has access to frequent transit and amenities such as parks, look so much different than Rainier Valley? Where is all the blue?

author: Connor Stein
content: Voters have approved multiple generational investments in light rail transit. To not even allow the potential for dense, high rise housing close to light rail stations is an abject failure.

author: Connor Stein
content: Maybe the one bright spot in this entire plan. Small, grandfathered corner stores and cafes are some of Seattle's most beloved places. Why then do we not allow more of them? This is a step in the right direction.

author: Connor Stein
content: Redeveloping a former single family lot into 4 detached houses with no yard and no trees is also part of this equation. We need to be incentivizing development that doesn't worsen stormwater runoff issues. Stacked flats, sixplexes, 8plexes, oh my!

author: Randy Davidson
content: This whole update is a fiasco if frequent transit routes are not maxed out for the highest density. They run through almost every neighborhood, obviously they have transit and they are either right next to or on the way to all services one needs. They are the key and this plan underutilizes them to a criminal degree. As a friend of mine said, "If a bus runs by your house every 10 minutes, you are not living in a single family neighborhood." Only in Seattle with its crew of dinosaur planners is that not the case. Disgraceful and Disgusting.

author: Connor Stein
content: This is a great idea, but in order for the businesses that occupy these future corner stores to be viable we need to allow more dense housing around them. More housing = more customers.

author: Connor Stein
content: What measurable benefit is provided by controlling the design of new developments? These standards often lead to ugly and unnecessarily complicated buildings that cost more to build and provide worse layouts for residents. We should care less about controlling the minutiae of architectural design and more about providing high quality, affordable housing with access to daylight and cross ventilation.

author: Connor Stein
content: Please look at the provided neighborhood residential concepts document released with this draft and tell me which development has better access to light, air, and open space—the ridiculous detached houses with 5' of space between all of the exterior walls, or small apartment buildings with full floor stacked flats. This is simply unserious.

author: Connor Stein
content: This type of micro-management is obstructionist and unnecessary.

author: Connor Stein
content: Do you know what makes snow days in Seattle so magical? There are very few cars generating the type of noise this section is describing. We need to plan for transit and housing that make car dependency a thing of the past.

author: Connor Stein
content: This policy should be inverted. If you want to build a less dense development than what is allowed, you should have to mitigate the opportunity cost of housing lost. If you are tearing down an old detached house to build a new, larger detached house, you are harming the city more than any multifamily development.

author: Connor Stein
content: NO! There should be no design review, full stop. As a former member of a design review board, I cannot think of a single instance where the process made a building demonstrably better. The guidelines are enforced arbitrarily by board members. There is little to no tangible benefit of this program. It only serves to delay projects and make them more expensive, the cost of which is passed on to the tenants.

author: Connor Stein
content: These zones needed to have a higher FAR. If the FAR is limited to 0.9 as shown elsewhere, developers aren't going to build (6) 750 square foot units. They're going to build (3) 1500 square foot units, unnecessarily limiting the potential supply of housing.

author: Isaac Gloor
content: As a city that represents a beacon of progressive vaues, and an island of liberal values in a conservative landscape, we should be planning to house as many people as we can. This plan has no vision for how Seattle becomes the City of 2044. Our regional centers are the only zones that allow high-rise residential housing. A city with affordable rent and vibrant neighborhoods does not restrict enormous quantities of land from being lived on by any but the wealthy- and thats what this plan does. Our regional centers should be growing to represent the actual need for high-density housing. Townhomes and small apartment buildings are great but will not get us where we need to go. Allow high-density uses around parks, around lakes, everywhere near transit. Stop arbitrarily limiting the potential that this City has for greatness and let it grow to become what Seattleites want it to be.

author: Erin Phillips
content: By putting density only in the most expensive parts of the city you are placing even more housing out of the reach of average working/middle class Seattleites (is that the goal?). To actually help with affordability you need to find the least expensive and most likely to be redeveloped areas in each neighborhood to site large apartment buildings and those are the frequent transit routes. Do the right thing please.

author: Julia Holden
content: This area is near a park and has frequent transit which is where we should be increasing density. Why is this area not included?

author: Kyle Stevens
content: One thing that would help a ton would be to classify frequent transit routes with 2 or more lanes each way (Aurora, 15th) different than the ones that go into neighborhoods and have one lane each way. The ones with one lane each way are ideal for apartments as they have all the transit convenience and near stores but without the crazy non-stop traffic, noise,etc. Those areas are totally different and should reflect that on maps as one is perfect for people to live the other for businesses to visit, work.

author: Taryn Greenwood
content: Yes please!! Fund our libraries!

author: Blake Zobrist
content: Seattle needs to give up on the delusion that urban home ownership is a sustainable path to prosperity for most people. It is not the 1950s anymore - people with enough to afford a house in Seattle have already built up plenty of wealth, and catering to the unrealistic expectation that housing will forever pay off as a personal investment will only make housing more expensive. Actually building enough housing to meet demand is a much better place to start building wealth, but this plan fails to do even that.

author: E.J. Foust
content: There are several areas where Urban Centers come within blocks of connecting to each other on this map. Why did you not just connect them, which would simplify zoning and strengthen the plan?

author: E.J. Foust
content: Connect these three West Seattle urban centers

author: E.J. Foust
content: Connect these four North Seattle Urban Centers

author: Sam Blanchard
content: Focusing on apartment building should be the overwhelming priority. People need shelter much more than this generational wealth attempt. We tried that before with no money down, ninja, liar loans and the system crashed. Europe has much higher renter rates than us and people are just fine. Pushing ownership on people who cannot or do not want the responsibility and hassle of owning is wrong. But surprise! The lenders are all over this and push it because if it goes bad Uncle Sam (taxpayers) will bail them out. Just build apartments and stop with the economic/social engineering.

author: Blake Zobrist
content: These "urban neighborhoods" are sprawls of single family housing. A community made up primarily or entirely of low-density residential uses has no place in a modern, well-designed city, and Seattle cannot become one of those while leaving most of the city covered by "urban neighborhoods." Development in Regional and Urban centers is wasted when they're separated by unproductive car-centric suburbs - living in one of these centers becomes a commodity of its own because they actually have decent urban amenities (mixed use, walkability, transit access, etc); even if One Seattle planned for enough housing to reduce prices, this would undercut it. I would like to see denser housing and mixed uses on quieter streets throughout the city - "urban neighborhoods" should get less than half of what they do now, if even that.

author: Blake Zobrist
content: This plan is an outrageous disappointment in every way, underpromising on essential solutions to the housing crisis, homelessness, climate change, and the damage homogenous low-density residential development has done to Seattle, both financial and to our city's urban character. One Seattle will not build enough housing to meet growing demand (much less already existing demand), it doubles down on the failed urban village strategy which constrains development, and the most it does to address climate change, racial disparities, and transit/pedestrian oriented development is mentioning them every now and again for appearances. We know what makes a healthy, vibrant, modern city, and One Seattle ain't it.

author: Connor Stein
content: 60,000 net new homes over this period divides out to 6,000 new homes per year. This plan creates capacity for 100,000 new homes over 20 years. That would mean, in the absolute best case scenario, we would still be falling short of the level of housing production that left us in the hole that we're in. We need to significantly increase our capacity for potential homes by dramatically upzoning the entire city.

author: Jesse Garfield
content: Here in Queen Anne you need to rezone to allow large apartments on the frequent transit routes that run on: 3rd Ave West, Taylor Ave North and 10th Ave West in that order of priority. 3rd W. has 3 bus lines, Taylor 2 and 10th has one. These are not dangerous, loud, polluted arterials like Aurora and 15th West. They are perfect for apartments and need to be zoned for that. Near services, shops, schools and parks with quick transit to job centers. Ideal, Just Do It!!

author: David Ogden
content: White Center residents should be allowed to vote if they want to join Seattle or not. Burien may be a better choice for them. They have voted down annexation multiple times.

author: David Ogden
content: Need more rapid transit in this part of West Seattle.

author: David Ogden
content: Need A LOT more rapid transit in Magnolia, especially to Discovery Park.

author: David Ogden
content: Need more rapid transit in this part of West Seattle.

author: David Ogden
content: Need to have King County Metro and Sound Transit coordinate schedules better even now. It is of no help to have busses depart every 15 minutes if you arrive after a 30 minute trip and then and still have to wait another 15 minutes. By that point people are better off driving a shared car.

author: David Ogden
content: Strong "NO" to changing single family, DADU, or ADU height restrictions above current limits. Nothing over 35' please unless it is in an Urban Area. Crowding out the open space on a lot in an Urban Neighborhood does not improve the character or feel of a neighborhood. But, I imagine that will still move forward. Please do not crowd out the view scape above the current limit and get into a bunch of height limit wars.

author: Joe Aman
content: This draft completely ignores the previous round of public feedback, which overwhelmingly favored more housing (i.e. Alternatives 5 & 6).  This is closer to Alternative 2:  a tepid increase in housing that will never meet demand.  It is a plan for rent to increase even further.

author: Julia Peterson
content: Must agree with other posters that this draft is a meek, weak effort that totally ignored the comments from 2022. Thousands of them and by a mile option 5 & 6 were the choice. This sad sack of a draft is like option 1.5. Not even number 2, just as close to do nothing #1. What a blown chance to do something and listen to the people. Very very disappointed 😞

author: Jane Smith
content: UPZONE LAURELHURST

author: Joe Aman
content: Is a high cost of living part of Seattle's unique character?  If so, I think this plan does a great job of preserving it.

author: Russell
content: These urban neighborhoods need a ton more housing for Seattle to be able to house all its residents affordably. Restricting development in any of these so-called urban neighborhoods will only contribute to further sprawl and rising costs of housing. There's no reason why large apartment buildings shouldn't be going up in all of these urban neighborhoods. Once the density of people increases, the commercial development will follow. It makes no sense to limit housing development of these areas now. They're already so close to business districts by transit, walking, and rolling; it is a heinous hand-out to already wealthy single family homeowners to protect these urban neighborhoods, which are IN the city , from true urban development. The proposed middle housing will only add just one or two housing units here or there but large apartment buildings everywhere across the city are needed to actually substantially increase Seattle's housing stock.

author: Joe Aman
content: GS 1.4 calls for more housing around parks, which I think is a great idea.  But this map says otherwise!  It maintains low-density zoning around all major parks in the city.

author: Joe Aman
content: Why maintain this island of low-density housing?  This should be a regional center or urban center

author: Frank Morales
content: Where to begin? Almost two hundred pages of big talk and proclamations about redressing any and all prior wrongs through this legislation but talk is all there is. The red-lining lives on. The denial of BIPOC majority neighborhoods of benefitting from density because? They think we are too simpleminded to understand real estate. How belittling and condescending. Typical high hat behavior from the worst kind of prejudice there is, assuming we are just ignorant and need their laws to protect us from them. We want to participate not be talked down to and treated like simpletons. High risk of displacement is just Jim Crow code for stay where you are and don't you dare climb the ladder.

author: Joe Aman
content: There is a ton of language in this document that basically says "taller buildings shouldn't be next to shorter buildings."  Why is this a worthy goal?

author: Aditya
content: In addition to light rail, why now allow higher height limits near frequent bus routes as well?

author: Aditya
content: Does "preserve Seattle's existing street grid" refer to preserving the grid for car access? While I support preserving the grid for pedestrian/bike access, I believe the plan should permit converting existing car streets to pedestrian ones.

author: Hunter
content: We need to reduce personal vehicle access across the city. No personal vehicles should be allowed in Pike Place Market. Reduce personal vehicle access in areas like the Pike/Pine corridor during peak hours (particularly weekends and evenings). Reduce vehicle traffic around farmers markets.
